title: Are songs of this generation meaningless? - Quora

response.answer_text: I always said I wouldn't be one of those people that wouldn't give the next generations music a chance. I consider my generation 60s & 70s music. I love it. I love 80s & 90s music. As the new millennium started, something changed. A few years ago , I went to a Don Henley concert. At the start, he asked “what's happened to music?” Many factors have caused the downward spiral. The internet has affected how music is made and sold. Radio is dying. There aren't bands anymore. Nobody goes to a record store anymore. Free music is everywhere. The younger generation has grown up with rap hip hop and auto tune. They must be entertained with visual affects and dancers to be stimulated. Many artists aren't writing and creating music anymore. Many can no longer make a living at it. And to answer your question, there are still a few meaningful songs. Just not very many. Rap and hip hop is not music. Music has rythym and melody. And the pop songs of today are over produced with nobody playing the instruments. They sound the same. Nothing unique. That you could say makes them meaningless.

Don’t go there. Seriously. Songs of this generation don’t speak to you, or me, for that matter. They’re not meant to. They’re not written for you and me. Then again, maybe you’re simply not finding the music that would have meaning for you. I mean, there’s more music out there now than ever before and more ways to find it than ever before. If all you’re listening to is the radio and whatever Spotify is feeding you, you’ll very rarely hear anything that speaks to you. Good music often requires a little work from the listener, and so does finding it. I hated it when the older generation constantly knocked the music that meant, that still means, SO much to me when I was a kid; I swore that I’d never do that when I was older and I’d combat this very line of thinking forever. Who the hell are we to judge? Every new generation takes a whole rash of grief from the older. Always have and probably always will, and it’s just so futile and pointless and just creates needless divisions between generations. Do I like much of today’s popular music? No, not really. But I’ve never really liked much popular music, especially when it was current.

Are songs of this generation meaningless?  Serious musicians would say no. But what is advertised is the lowest common denominator, which, sarcastically, is the pre-braces group. To them, Taylor Swift’s peers have AARP cards.
Not to this generation, no. Every generation has “their music.” From Big Band, to Rock n’Roll, to Disco, to HipHop, to whatever, each generation’s music is meaningful to them.
No! This song is very meaningful! What do you think about it?
